awd_titl_txt: Core Collapse Supernova Gravitational Wave Signature Predictions based on 3D Ab Initio Models with Increasing GR Realism
awd_abstract_narration:
The death of massive stars in core collapse supernovae (CCSNe) is directly or indirectly responsible for the largest share of the elements in the Periodic Table. CCSNe involve extremes in density and other quantities. Newtonian gravity is insufficient to describe such extremes. Einsteinian gravity is needed. This project advance the treatment of gravity in supernova models from a Newtonian treatment with a correction to account for some Einsteinian effects, to a far more sophisticated treatment of Einsteinian gravity, thereby advancing the realism of CCSNe models significantly. As such, researchers will be better positioned to predict gravitational wave (GW), a ripple in the fabric of space-time, emission in CCSNe, among the sources that produce GWs detectable by LIGO. This project will support the training of a graduate student in supernova theory and will provide (i) a bridge between the supernova modeling community and the LSC via the Supernova Multi-messenger Consortium, (ii) organized lectures on relativity as part of a Physics Academy at a local, diverse public high school, and (iii) public lectures on relativity and supernovae.
 
Advanced multi-physics models of core collapse supernovae (CCSNe), which include multi-frequency neutrino transport with a complete set of neutrino interactions and relativistic corrections such as gravitational redshift, have implemented an effective gravitational potential given by the Newtonian potential (obtained by solving the Poisson equation) plus a correction to the monopole term (obtained from an integral formulation of the Tolman-Oppenheimer-Volkoff equation using angle-averaged densities). More realistic models will require more realistic treatments of general relativistic gravity. This project will support the implementation of the Conformally Flat Approximation across all model components: gravity, hydrodynamics, and neutrino transport. The PI and his collaborators will compute the emission of gravitational waves (GWs) in the CCSN models and will work closely with members of the LIGO Scientific Collaboration to optimize GW predictions for their use.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Massive stars, ten times the mass of the Sun or more massive, die in catastrophic explosions known as core collapse supernovae. They are directly or indirectly responsible for the production of the lion’s share of the elements in the Periodic Table, without which life as we know it would not exist. Ascertaining the ``central engine’’ responsible for these explosions is one of the most important goals in astrophysics. We now know that core collapse supernovae are powered by radiation in the form of particles called neutrinos. The neutrinos literally boil the central regions of the star, generating turbulent explosive outflows. The goals of this project were three-fold: (1) Develop a solver for the Einstein equations – i.e., to determine the strong gravitational fields present in these dense, energetic environments, where gravity is not well described by Newton’s theory. (2) Develop a solver for the equations of general relativistic hydrodynamics – i.e., hydrodynamics in strong gravitational fields. (3) Develop predictions for the gravitational wave emission from core collapse supernovae. The project was carried out by two graduate students and represented important components of the students’ Ph.D. research, adding an important workforce training dimension.

Developments (1) and (2) led to the creation of two modules within our next-generation core collapse supernova simulation framework called THORNADO. These modules will be used in conjunction with a module for general relativistic neutrino radiation transport being developed under a separate project. All three modules will be coupled together in our next-generation core collapse supernova simulations (relative to our current generation of simulations). Given the physics included, especially considering that it will be included in a way that is consistent with Einsteinian (strong) gravity (i.e., general relativity), the simulations will be among the state-of-the-art simulations performed by supernova groups around the world, moving us a significant step closer toward ascertaining the core collapse supernova central engine.

Regarding development (3): Gravitational waves are ripples in the fabric of spacetime caused by explosive events such as core collapse supernovae. They bear the signature of the central engine. As such, their detection would provide a way to validate core collapse supernova models. Successful engagement between our supernova team and members of the LIGO Scientific Collaboration (LSC) associated with the Laser Interferometer Gravitational Observatory (LIGO) was established during the project. On our end, predictions of core collapse supernova gravitational wave “signatures” were provided. On the LSC end, these signatures were analyzed for detection and so-called parameter estimation, the latter of which relates to determining characteristics of the astrophysical system from the detection of its gravitational wave emission.

In addition to the activities outlined above, outreach to public high schools within the Knox County School System was conducted, involving classroom lectures on Einstein’s theory of relativity to high school juniors and seniors in both AP and IB physics programs. In addition, outreach to the general public was conducted through public lectures. 

The activities supported by this award led to publications in refereed journals, presentations given internationally, and open-source simulation software.
